title: The Meaning Behind Sabrina Carpenterâ€™s Hit "Espresso"

steps.title: "Espresso" is about reveling in your own self-confidence.
steps.content: "Espresso" is about reveling in your own self-confidence. â€œThe song is kind of about seeing femininity as your superpower, and embracing the confidence of being that b*tch,â€ she told Vogue . [1] X Research source Carpenterâ€™s joy and faith in herself and her seductive abilities are evident throughout the song in the energetic, totally danceable nu-funk beat and the bubbly, flirtatious lyrics like â€œI can't relate to desperation. / My â€œgive-a-f*cksâ€ are on vacationâ€ or the iconic â€œThatâ€™s that me espresso.â€ â€œI just thought I was the s*it in the moment, andâ€¦you donâ€™t always feel that way so you kind of have to capture those moments that you do,â€ Carpenter revealed in an interview for New Music Daily . [2] X Research source â€œFor me, equating [that feeling] to caffeine and that addiction was really fun. And I definitely have a caffeine addiction as it is, so it really ends up being a full circle for me.â€ â€œâ€˜My give-a-f*cks are on vacationâ€™â€”itâ€™s such a simple, funny line,â€ she says, â€œbut so much of this song really kind of gets to a place where it really measures up with where Iâ€™m at right now, andâ€¦you have to go through life to get thereâ€¦. Iâ€™m just having fun now.â€

steps.title: "Espresso" is also about the joy of knowing someone is addicted to you.
steps.content: "Espresso" is also about the joy of knowing someone is addicted to you. Espresso isnâ€™t just a metaphor for how Carpenter feels about herselfâ€”itâ€™s also an apt description for how addictive, energizing, and hot she is to the songâ€™s unnamed romantic interest: â€œNow he's thinkin' 'bout me every night, oh, / Is it that sweet? I guess so. / Say you can't sleep, baby, I know, / That's that me espresso.â€ The song is full of sexual innuendo as well, like in the lyrics, â€œThat morning coffee, brewed it for ya, / One touch and I brand-newed it for yaâ€ or â€œMove it up, down, left, right, oh, / Switch it up like Nintendo.â€ Fans like TikToker @emilyxinfinity have pointed out that the sexual innuendo seems to go over some listenersâ€™ heads, possibly because they havenâ€™t grasped figurative language, they want to police womenâ€™s sexual agency, or they assume a beautiful pop star like Carpenter isnâ€™t clever enough to think of lines like â€œMountain Dew it for yaâ€ (â€œmount and do it for yaâ€). As TikTok user Ashley Ibarria commented on @emilyxinfinityâ€™s video, â€œTo make espresso, you grind the coffee beansâ€¦. You GRIND on the BEAN to make espresso.â€ [3] X Research source

steps.title: Itâ€™s linguistically oddâ€¦and therefore mesmerizing.
steps.content: Itâ€™s linguistically oddâ€¦and therefore mesmerizing. The song is full of what Alex Abad-Santos at Vox aptly calls â€œsexy clown wordplay.â€ [4] X Research source Basically immediately after â€œEspressoâ€ was released, listeners were hooked on its catchy, unusual, and often grammatically absurd lyrics like â€œdream-came-trueâ€™d it for ya,â€ â€œmy give-a-f*cks are on vacation,â€ and of course, â€œthatâ€™s that me espresso.â€ The lyrics have served as inspo for countless memes, and many a linguist has lost sleep over-analyzing the songâ€™s lyrical brilliance (we assume). Musicologist Nate Sloan and songwriter Charlie Hardingâ€”co-hosts of the music podcast Switched on Pop â€”theorize, â€œâ€˜Espressoâ€™ plays with language in a way that takes your brain a moment to processâ€¦. It keeps listeners on their toes.â€ [5] X Research source While memes can be brutal, the meme-ification of â€œEspressoâ€ seems mostly done out of love. Carpenter takes it in stride, even sharing some fansâ€™ memes to her social media account, like this one . [6] X Research source

steps.title: â€œThatâ€™s that me espresso,â€ specifically, lives rent-free in our brains.
steps.content: â€œThatâ€™s that me espresso,â€ specifically, lives rent-free in our brains. Itâ€™s not the only off-kilter lyric in Carpenterâ€™s hot girl anthem, but itâ€™s the one weâ€™re obsessed with the mostâ€”partly because itâ€™s unclear exactly what the lyric means, and partly because itâ€™s unclear if thereâ€™s a comma before â€œespressoâ€ or not, which could affect how the lyric is interpreted, if only very slightly. â€œThatâ€™s that me espressoâ€ might suggest that the espresso Carpenter is singing about is of the â€œmeâ€ variety. Itâ€™s â€œmeâ€-flavored. Itâ€™s giving â€œme.â€ On the other hand, you might interpret â€œThatâ€™s that me, espressoâ€ as Carpenter saying, â€œThatâ€™s me,â€ and then using â€œespressoâ€ as a direct metaphor for herself to showcase how addictive and energizing and hot she is (which we canâ€™t disagree with).

steps.title: The video begins with Sabrina driving a boat with a hot guy in the back.
steps.content: The video begins with Sabrina driving a boat with a hot guy in the back. Our girl is literally in the driverâ€™s seat, which sets the tone for the entire song. When she intentionally swerves the boat, knocking the guy overboard, she steals his wallet and treats herself and her gal pals to a day of sun and fun on the beach with a crew of hot guys fawning over them. The music video, directed by acclaimed music video director Dave Meyers, takes place in a dreamy, stylized 1950s beach setting, where the sun is hot and the babes are hotter. ğŸ’… â€œSince the day I heard the song, I saw a beach atmosphere,â€ Carpenter said, â€œâ€”and more specifically this kind of old school [and] modern environment. [I wanted to capture] the playfulness that I like to use throughout all of my videos. I also just wanted a pool car, to be frank.â€ [7] X Research source Itâ€™s giving Barbie Landâ€”which is probably intentional: Carpenter references the 2023 smash hit in the context of â€œEspressoâ€ in a number of her TikTok videos, including this one and this one . The singer has also been compared to Betty Boop , Polly Pocket , and a Bratz doll (in fact, now she is a Bratz doll ).

steps.title: The video ends with Carpenter being arrested.
steps.content: The video ends with Carpenter being arrested. The guy she ditched at the beginning of the song comes back around with the cops in tow, and they handcuff a beaming, fancy-free Carpenter. The last shot of the video is of Carpenter relaxing in the back of the cop car. The video, like the song, definitely speaks to Carpenterâ€™s ability to keep a guy â€œwrapped â€˜round [her] finger,â€ as basically all the male characters spend the video swooning over and serving Carpenter (and her girlfriends). But much of the power she possesses in the music video is financial, in contrast with the song, which focuses primarily on Carpenterâ€™s powers of seduction.

steps.title: Carpenter came up with the song while drinking espresso in Paris in 2023.
steps.content: Carpenter came up with the song while drinking espresso in Paris in 2023. According to a Rolling Stone interview the pop star did in June 2024, the song had been rolling around in her head since July 2023 while she was spending some time in France after a tour. â€œI decided to put that burden on other people,â€ she says. [8] X Research source Literally, what a queen. The song was written by Carpenter, along with Amy Allen, Steph Jones, and Julian Bunetta.

steps.title: Carpenter has described it as her second â€œbig girlâ€ album.
steps.content: Carpenter has described it as her second â€œbig girlâ€ album. Short nâ€™ Sweet is technically Carpenterâ€™s sixth studio album, but itâ€™s only the second album released through Island Records, a label with whom she feels she has â€œcomplete creative control.â€ [9] X Research source Previously, she was locked into a contract with Disney-owned Hollywood Records, with whom she released 4 albums and felt more creatively stifled. Short n' Sweet was released on August 23, 2024, by Island Records and was produced by Julian Bunetta, John Ryan, Ian Kirkpatrick, and Jack Antonoff. Short nâ€™ Sweet received mostly positive reviews from critics who praised Carpenterâ€™s breezy songwriting and clever lyricism, though many found the lyrics low-risk. The album debuted at number 1 on the Billboard Hot 200, and all 12 songs were included in the Hot 100.

steps.title: The album focuses on themes of love and dating.
steps.content: The album focuses on themes of love and dating. â€œShort and sweetâ€ might describe Carpenter herself, at 4-foot-11-inches tall, or the relationships she sings about on the album: â€œsome of them were the shortest I've ever had, and they affected me the most,â€ she says. [10] X Research source Carpenter describes the album as the â€œhot older sisterâ€ of the album preceding it, Emails I Canâ€™t Send , her first with Island.

steps.title: â€œPlease Please Pleaseâ€
steps.content: â€œPlease Please Pleaseâ€ The second single off Short nâ€™ Sweet after â€œEspresso,â€ â€œPlease Please Pleaseâ€ is a disco-y, country pop, yacht rock song. (She really does it all!) The song is about feeling insecure in a relationship with someone who doesn't treat you how they should, and worried your heart could be broken at any moment: â€œHeartbreak is one thing, my egoâ€™s another, / I beg you donâ€™t embarrass me, mother f*cker,â€ she sings in the chorus. [11] X Research source The music video picks up where â€œEspressoâ€â€™s leaves off, with Carpenter in jailâ€”and it stars Carpenterâ€™s off-screen boyfriend, Saltburn star Barry Keoghan, as a dangerous criminal with whom she falls in love. Director Bardia Zeinali explained the video is â€œabout this person that Sabrina's character keeps falling for, that has this chaotic behavior.â€ [12] X Research source But the video ends with â€œa role reversal and an exchange of power towards the end,â€ with Carpenter tying Keoghanâ€™s character up and placing duct tape over his mouth, kissing him, and walking away. [13] X Research source

steps.title: â€œTasteâ€
steps.content: â€œTasteâ€ â€œTasteâ€ is the third single off Short nâ€™ Sweet . In this bouncy rock tune, Carpenter sings about her rivalry with the girl dating one of her exesâ€”played in the music video by Wednesday and Beetlejuice, Beetlejuice star Jenna Ortega. The theme of the song is summed up in these lyrics from the chorus: â€œI heard you're back together and if that's true / You'll just have to taste me when he's kissin' you. / If you want forever, and I bet you do, / Just know you'll taste me too.â€ The music video â€”once again directed by Dave Meyersâ€”involves Carpenter and Ortega in a war over the boyfriend. The two rivals are stuck in an endless loop of killing each other in comedically gruesome waysâ€”but theyâ€™re also kinda horny for each other too. [14] X Research source The video alludes primarily to the 1992 film Death Becomes Her , starring Meryl Streep and Goldie Hawn as rivals (just with added horniness levels). It also features references to the movies Psycho , Addams Family Values , Ginger Snaps , and Kill Bill: Volume 1 .
